titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Freedom to Marry Records
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Camila Zorrilla Tessler

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:28

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract:
Freedom to Marry (2003-2015) was an organization and campaign founded by Evan Wolfson in 2003, with the sole purpose of legalizing marriage for same-sex couples at both the state and federal level. The campaign formulated a three-part strategy to accomplish its goals: win marriage equality in more states, build support for marriage equality, and end federal discrimination. Freedom to Marry's campaign culminated in 2015 when the Supreme Court decided the landmark case, Obergefell v. Hodges, in favor of marriage equality for same-sex couples.
The Freedom to Marry records include incorporation documents, meeting minutes, grant applications, promotional material, correspondence, office memos, legal cases, briefs, amici curiae, administrative files, research files, polling files, websites, and audiovisual materials created by, about, and for Freedom to Marry, a bipartisan campaign, to attain marriage equality for same-sex couples in the United States. The organization's records focus almost exclusively on this goal, and the few materials that do not are related to civil rights for the LGBTQ+ (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans, Queer, plus) community. Materials are dated from 1948 to 2016 with the bulk falling between 2003 and 2015, the years that the campaign was active. Material dated prior to 2000 is related to the organization either as historical context or research, or pertains specifically to Evan Wolfson's (Freedom to Marry's founder and president) career prior to the establishment of Freedom to Marry.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Freedom to Marry (2003-2015) was an organization and campaign founded by Evan Wolfson in 2003, with the sole purpose of legalizing marriage for same-sex couples at both the state and federal level. The campaign formulated a three-part strategy to accomplish its goals: win marriage equality in more states, build support for marriage equality, and end federal discrimination. Freedom to Marry's campaign culminated in 2015 when the Supreme Court decided the landmark case, Obergefell v. Hodges, in favor of marriage equality for same-sex couples.

The marriage equality movement gained a victory in 1993 when Evan Wolfson and Dan Foley argued for and won marriage equality in Hawaii before the Hawaii Supreme Court in the case Baehr v. Miike. Despite this victory, anti-marriage equality groups convinced Hawaii to pass a constitutional amendment forbidding same-sex marriage. This was the first of many DOMAs (Defense of Marriage Acts) and Super DOMAs, which defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for the purposes of state and federal law. Recognizing that for marriage equality to become a reality an affirmative and strategic campaign would be needed, the Evelyn & Walter Haas Jr. Fund approached Wolfson in 2000. Together, Wolfson and the Haas Fund created Freedom to Marry as a sustained affirmative campaign designed to work towards the goal of marriage equality in the United States. The campaign designed a strategy to advocate for marriage equality at the state and federal level. The Evelyn & Walter Haas Jr. Fund seeded Freedom to Marry with a $2.5 million grant.

Freedom to Marry incorporated as a nonprofit in 2003, and was overseen by a board and steering committee with Wolfson acting as president. The structure of Freedom to Marry included departments focused on communications, development, research, political operations, and campaign programs. Freedom to Marry used a three-part strategy which included winning marriage equality in more states, building and growing majority support for marriage, and ending federal discrimination. This strategy, known as the Roadmap to Victory, argued that marriage equality did not need to win every state, but simply enough states to encourage the higher branches of the United States government to act. This strategy formed the foundation for their campaign, which included funding partner organizations through regranting programs, mounting legal challenges in the court, lobbying and political fundraising, and community organization. Freedom to Marry also had a marketing strategy to extend their message to the public.

On June 26, 2015, the Supreme Court of the United States legalized same-sex marriage on a federal level by releasing its decision in Obergefell v. Hodges. On July 9, 2015, Freedom to Marry declared that the campaign was over and the organization was dissolved, as they'd achieved their goal of establishing marriage equality in the United States.
Information in this historical note was primarily drawn from the Freedom to Marry website, as well as from the annual reports found in the Program Files series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Freedom to Marry records include incorporation documents, meeting minutes, grant applications, promotional material, correspondence, office memos, legal cases, briefs, amici curiae, administrative files, research files, polling files, websites, and audiovisual materials created by, about, and for Freedom to Marry, a bipartisan campaign, to attain marriage equality for same-sex couples in the United States. The organization's records focus almost exclusively on this goal, and the few materials that do not are related to civil rights for the LGBTQ+ (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans, Queer, plus) community. Materials are dated from 1948 to 2016 with the bulk falling between 2003 and 2015, the years that the campaign was active. Material dated prior to 2000 is related to the organization either as historical context or research, or pertains specifically to Evan Wolfson's (Freedom to Marry's founder and president) career prior to the establishment of Freedom to Marry.

Evan Wolfson's professional papers (Series I) document Wolfson's career prior to the foundation of Freedom to Marry and include material from Wolfson's time at Lambda Legal, including legal briefs relating to his casework. A bulk of these briefs relate to the case Boy Scouts of American and Monmouth Council, Boy Scouts of America v. James Dale. Wolfson's professional papers document his wide breadth of research for his cases and his leadership within the organizations Lambda Legal and Freedom to Marry. Wolfson's professional papers date from between approximately 1990-2009.

Administrative documents (Series II) detail the organization, activities, and history of Freedom to Marry. These, along with the annual reports, job descriptions and job search documents, the papers of Samiya Bashir, the communication director, and the papers of Thalia Zepatos, director of research and messaging, contain information on the day-to-day running of Freedom to Marry from its inception in 2003 to its culmination in 2015. Additionally, the website provides a significant understanding of the history, structure, and mission of Freedom to Marry.

These records also detail the marketing and financial strategies used by Freedom to Marry and their work with partner organizations. Financial records, such as regranting files and annual reports, demonstrate the partnerships between Freedom to Marry and other civil rights and equal marriage organizations, particularly the Human Rights Campaign, GLAD (GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders), GLAAD (once known as Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation), Lambda Legal, and the ACLU (American Civil Liberties Union). There is also a significant collection of press clippings, research files, and published material tracking the victories and losses of the marriage equality movement across the United States.

Audiovisual materials (Series VII) consist primarily of television publicity that advocates for marriage equality, or programming produced for or about Freedom to Marry promoting the campaign. Recordings of community events and town halls debating marriage equality are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged in seven series: I. Evan Wolfson Files, 1948-2009. II. Administrative Records, 2005-2011. III. Development Files, 2003-2012. IV. Program Files, 1973-2016. V. Regrant Files, 2001-2009. VI. Director of Public Engagement and Director of Research and Messaging Files, 2005-2016. VI. Audiovisual Materials, 1986-2013.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Freedom to Marry Records have three levels of access: open to researchers, open with permission from the donors, and closed until 2035.
Series I is closed to researchers until 2035.
Series II-VI have specific access details at the series level.

Series VII is comprised of original audiovisual material. Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the creator(s) of this collection for unpublished works they have authored or otherwise produced. After the date when the creator ceases to exist or January 1, 2035, whichever comes first, copyright passes to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Commercially produced material, including books, CDs, DVDs, and VHS tapes have been removed from the records.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Evan Wolfson (1957-) is an attorney and gay rights activist who was the founder and president of Freedom to Marry. He received a B.A. in American History from Yale College (1978) and a J.D. from Harvard Law School (1983). He has worked as a district attorney, a civil rights attorney, and as president of Freedom to Marry. He has been a continuous advocate and activist of marriage equality and gay rights in the United States.

While at Harvard, Wolfson wrote his thesis, Same-sex Marriage and Morality: The Human Rights Vision of the Constitution , on marriage equality for same-sex couples. This work became the foundation for his career. After his graduation from Harvard Law School he briefly taught political philosophy at Harvard College before serving as assistant district attorney for Kings County, New York. He also worked as a pro bono cooperating attorney for Lambda Legal between 1984 to 1989.

Wolfson worked at Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund and was the director of the Fund's Legal Marriage Project throughout the 1990s. During this time he served as co-counsel along with Dan Foley on Hawaii's landmark case for marriage equality, Baehr v. Miike. He became the first Lambda attorney to argue before the United States Supreme Court when he represented James Dale in Boy Scouts of America et. al. v. James Dale, a case which challenged the Boy Scouts for firing Scoutmaster James Dale due to his sexual orientation. In 2000, Wolfson left Lambda Legal to establish Freedom to Marry, where he focused on marriage equality. He served as president of Freedom to Marry from its inception in 2000 until its dissolution in 2015.

Wolfson wrote the book Why Marriage Matters: America, Equality, and Gay People's Right to Marry , published in 2004. He has also written many articles on marriage equality and gay rights. He won numerous awards in honor of his work to ensure marriage equality, including the MassMutual Vow to Protect award and the Barnard Medal of Distinction. He has been named Distinguished Visitor from Practice at Georgetown Law Center, Distinguished Practitioner in Grand Strategy at Yale University, and Senior Counsel at Dentons.
Information found in this biographical note has been drawn from the Freedom to Marry website.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Series I, Evan Wolfson Files, is closed until 1 January 2035 per the collection's deed of gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Evan Wolfson Files series contains the professional papers of Evan Wolfson, the founder of Freedom to Marry, from his time as an attorney to his work with the Freedom to Marry organization. This series contains Wolfson's early marriage organizing files from his work before the foundation of Freedom to Marry, as well as material from his work with Lambda, Freedom to Marry administration documents, press clippings, legal documents from his time as a practicing attorney, and case files for the Boy Scouts et al. v. James Dale United States Supreme Court case. The papers in this series range from 1948 to 2009, but the bulk fall between the years of 1985 and 2005.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into six groupings: General, Early marriage organizing files, Freedom to Marry files, Lambda Legal files, Press clippings, and Research files.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The bulk of series II, Administrative Records, is closed until 1 January 2035 per the collection's deed of gift. Materials in box 45 cannot be accessed without permission from the donor until 1 January 2035.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Administrative records series contains incorporation documents and records pertaining to day-to-day running of Freedom to Marry, as well as office documents and material regarding staffing and procedures.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Material in boxes 48-53 cannot be accessed without permission from the donor until 1 January 2035, per the collection's deed of gift. Box 47 is open to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Development Files series contains annual reports, donor information and meeting minutes and other documents pertaining to donor relations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Development Files is organized in two groupings: annual reports, and donor files.

did.unittitle: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) of California

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Program Files (Series IV) has three levels of access per the collection's deed of gift. Materials in boxes 54-92 are open to researchers. Materials in boxes 93-157 cannot be accessed without permission from the donor until 1 January 2035, and materials in boxes 158-160 cannot be accessed until 1 January 2035.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Additionally, boxes 82-92 and 131-157 are audiovisual materials. Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs series covers programs that were run by, funded by, or partnered with Freedom to Marry. This includes schedules, pamphlets, communications, publications, partner organization files, and contains some regranting material that was not included in the Regranting series because it includes more information on the partner organizations. Evan Wolfson material that is included in this series is material about Wolfson, and not his professional papers.

The Program files also contain captures of Freedom to Marry's internet presence, which includes social media, the official Freedom to Marry website, and videos produced by Freedom to Marry. Not included are state-level sites for Freedom to Marry.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Programs series is organized in seven groupings: Subject files, Campaign files, Clippings, Polling files, Communication files, Partner organization files, Publications, and Internet and social media. This series is organized primarily chronologically, with the exception of the Clippings grouping and the Polling files grouping, which are organized chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is restricted until 2035 and may only be accessed with permission from the donor per the collection's deed of gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Regrant Files series consists of grant applications from partner organizations to Freedom to Marry. These files are almost exclusively grant applications and do not contain additional information about the partner organizations. Regranting material that includes additional information about partner organizations can be found in the Partner organization subseries of the Program Files series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Regrant Files series is organized chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Director of Public Engagement and Director of Research and Messaging Files series cannot be accessed per the collection's deed of gifts until 1 January 2035.
Boxes 168-174 cannot be accessed without permission from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Director of Public Engagement and Director of Research and Messaging Files series contains the research, correspondence, meeting minutes, project files, and professional papers of Thalia Zepatos, Freedom to Marry's Director of Research and Messaging.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Director of Public Engagement and Director of Research and Messaging Files is organized in five groupings: National collaborative files, Civil marriage collaborative files, State files, Research, messaging, and public education projects, and Research files. These groupings are organized in the original order in which they were received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual Materials series is comprised of television clips and segments (on VHS, DVD, and CD) concerning marriage equality. The bulk of this material was created by Freedom to Marry for television broadcast.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Audiovisual Materials series is comprised of four groupings: General, Evan Wolfson material, Freedom to Marry press clips, and Freedom to Marry produced material. These groupings are is organized alphabetically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The computer files are unprocessed and may contain sensitive information or be in a physical state that would prohibit use. Researchers wishing to request access should email mssa.assist@yale.edu . The request should outline the scope and purpose of the research project, why the researcher believes the material is relevant to their project, and contact information. If possible the request should also include a list of specific material of interest including collection, box, and folder numbers (or folder descriptions if folders are not numbered). The review may take several weeks.
